title: 103_s2479
content: The Act titled "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" aims to promote the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels. It includes an amendment regarding coastwise transportation of passengers. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation. The act includes regulations for coastwise passenger transportation, specifying ownership requirements and vessel documentation criteria. A vessel must be owned by a US citizen or entity, meet Merchant Marine Act requirements, and hold a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement. An exception is made for cruise vessels under an 18-month demise charter to a qualifying entity. The Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 exempts cruise vessels under an 18-month demise charter to a qualifying entity from certain ownership and documentation requirements. The vessels can operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after the charter ends with approval from the Secretary. Additionally, there is an exception for vessels not documented under chapter 121 of title 46, United States Code. The Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 exempts certain cruise vessels from ownership and documentation requirements if they meet specific criteria, including being between 5 and 15 years old and having a contract for the construction of another cruise vessel in the United States. This exemption does not apply after 18 months from the date of documentation. The Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for an exemption for certain cruise vessels from ownership and documentation requirements if they meet specific criteria. This exemption expires 18 months after the date of documentation, with a possible 6-month extension granted by the Secretary of Transportation for valid reasons. Additionally, individuals or related parties who own or charter a cruise vessel under this exemption are prohibited from operating any vessel between certain specified periods. The Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for exemptions for certain cruise vessels from ownership and documentation requirements. Owners or charterers of these vessels are restricted from operating between specific ports or Hawaii. Violations incur civil penalties, vessel seizure, and disqualification from coastwise trade. The Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows exemptions for certain cruise vessels from ownership and documentation requirements. Violations may result in civil penalties, vessel seizure, and disqualification from coastwise trade. The act defines coastwise trade and cruise vessels, imposing restrictions on vessel operations. The Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 exempts certain cruise vessels from ownership and documentation requirements if they meet specific criteria. The act defines related persons and imposes restrictions on vessel operations. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to deem certain vessels compliant with specific regulations and requirements for inspection and certification. Vessels meeting specified criteria are eligible for a certificate of inspection and authorization to engage in coastwise trade. The Act approved on June 19, 1886 abolishes fees for official services to American vessels and amends laws related to shipping commissioners, seamen, and vessel owners. SEC. 5 amends the Shipping Act, 1916 regarding citizenship for vessel operation in passenger transport. SEC. 6 amends the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 by including passenger and cargo. SEC. 7 addresses permits for vessels entering national park units. The Secretary of the Interior has priority rules for vessel operation in National Park System units. First priority is for vessels documented in the US or with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Second priority is for foreign-documented vessels already permitted. Third priority is for other vessels. The Secretary can revoke permits for foreign-documented vessels. The Secretary of the Interior can revoke permits for foreign-documented vessels in National Park System units if there is a limit on permits and someone with a US-documented vessel requests permission. However, this does not apply to individuals with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Those whose permits are revoked have the right to appeal. Any person whose permission to provide visitors services in a National Park System unit is revoked or not renewed has the right of first refusal to a permit when conditions no longer apply, as per section 1307(a) of the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act.
